title: Would-be Miss USA dissed by a gay judge?

content: quote: Originally posted by 21194237: What's up with that? The fact that Perez Hilton is a proessional gossip spreader and attention.....mogul. Chances are he probably knew her position before hand, and just wanted to stir up controversy for the $$. Personally, I think Perez is a wacko, and is doing more to harm gay rights than help. As for Miss Caliornia? I think everyone is entitled to their opinion, even if I disagree with it. I really don't think this is as newsworthy as it has been made out to be, and hate the fact that Mr. Hilton is being used as a yardstick for the gay community, but thats how the cookie crumbles, I guess.
quote: Originally posted by 21194237: What's up with that?
reply: The fact that Perez Hilton is a proessional gossip spreader and attention.....mogul. Chances are he probably knew her position before hand, and just wanted to stir up controversy for the $$. Personally, I think Perez is a wacko, and is doing more to harm gay rights than help. As for Miss Caliornia? I think everyone is entitled to their opinion, even if I disagree with it. I really don't think this is as newsworthy as it has been made out to be, and hate the fact that Mr. Hilton is being used as a yardstick for the gay community, but thats how the cookie crumbles, I guess.

title: Would-be Miss USA dissed by a gay judge?

content: quote: Originally posted by 21194237: On the other hand, had Miss California dissed gay people in a manner like she was, wouldn't that be a newsworthy item? I dont beleive so.
quote: Originally posted by 21194237: On the other hand, had Miss California dissed gay people in a manner like she was, wouldn't that be a newsworthy item?
title: Would-be Miss USA dissed by a gay judge?

content: A few points: 1. Beauty pageants are stupid. They've always been stupid, they'll always be stupid. Nothing better than a bunch of women parading themselves across stage in slinky gowns and cover-nothing bikinis and pretending that it's a scholarship competition. 2. Miss California is certainly entitled to her opinion. The audience is equally entitled to react to it. 3. Miss California wouldn't have won the competition anyway. From the reports I heard, she didn't win either the evening gown nor the swimsuit competition. Her stumbling, bumbling answer to the Q&A part of the competition had nothing to do with her win or loss. 4. Perez Hilton doesn't speak for anyone but himself. There are stupid straight people, and there are stupid gay people. Hell, look at Paris Hilton, and there's a fine example of a stupid straight person who says stupid things. 5. Even if Miss California had a shot at the crown, it was NOT the answer to her question, but HOW she answered it that would have lost. She fumbled, plain and simple. She didn't even make an attempt to formulate a social commentary about law, or the reasons for her opinions, or the facts behind the issue. Instead, from the transcript of her answer, she pretty much said, "I believe this because my mommy and daddy told me to." (ie. "I was raised to believe...") That's pretty weak. 6. It was a stupid question to ask in a pageant anyway. Beauty queens aren't necessarily deep thinkers. Look at Sarah Palin.

title: Would-be Miss USA dissed by a gay judge?

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: A few points: 1. Beauty pageants are stupid. They've always been stupid, they'll always be stupid. Nothing better than a bunch of women parading themselves across stage in slinky gowns and cover-nothing bikinis and pretending that it's a scholarship competition. 2. Miss California is certainly entitled to her opinion. The audience is equally entitled to react to it. 3. Miss California wouldn't have won the competition anyway. From the reports I heard, she didn't win either the evening gown nor the swimsuit competition. Her stumbling, bumbling answer to the Q&A part of the competition had nothing to do with her win or loss. 4. Perez Hilton doesn't speak for anyone but himself. There are stupid straight people, and there are stupid gay people. Hell, look at Paris Hilton, and there's a fine example of a stupid straight person who says stupid things. 5. Even if Miss California had a shot at the crown, it was NOT the answer to her question, but HOW she answered it that would have lost. She fumbled, plain and simple. She didn't even make an attempt to formulate a social commentary about law, or the reasons for her opinions, or the facts behind the issue. Instead, from the transcript of her answer, she pretty much said, "I believe this because my mommy and daddy told me to." (ie. "I was raised to believe...") That's pretty weak. 6. It was a stupid question to ask in a pageant anyway. Beauty queens aren't necessarily deep thinkers. Look at Sarah Palin. There's just too much here to let go without comment. 1. Beauty pageants have no IQ, so they are not stupid despite your opinion. They often lead contestants to very lucrative careers. 2. The reaction of the audience ought to be irrelevant to an objective judge. Otherwise, there is no need for a judge. 3. Contestants have won in the past despite not being number one in any of the individual competitions. 4. Greater care must be exercised to insure that people like Hilton are not given the authority of a judge. 5. You're among a minority of people who think that Miss California had no chance. Most people become who they are in large measure by how they were raised and there is nothing weak about it. 6. The question was quite obviously designed to bring an issue to the fore that ought not have been. The end result was that a young lady was publicly trashed for no good reason. She may or may not have been a 'deep thinker' and most of us aren't, either. Based on the collection of politicians currently running the country, it may be that Sarah Palin in considerably brighter in comparison. My heartburn comes primarily from Hilton's comment that ought to offend all women.

It was a stupid question to ask in a pageant anyway. Beauty queens aren't necessarily deep thinkers. Look at Sarah Palin.
